body:
> > This PR has two objectives:
> 
> you should have separated the PRs. Mixing refactoring and new feature makes review difficult. The behavir should not changed by refactoring while adding feature change behaviour.

Thank you, I was originally considering not opening too many PRs to increase the workload for reviewers, but it turns out my consideration was still not thorough. I will follow your suggestion to split them more simply.

@MacChen01 The originally reported issue is conflict between R and openblas-0.18.5.oe2203sp3. Is it not bug of openEuler? We can not expected it to be fixed? How about [installing R from source code as done for old Ubuntu](https://github.com/apache/bigtop/blob/0fbaaa90859a889dbd86b869895224fb7126f677/bigtop_toolchain/manifests/renv.pp#L87-L117) rather than sticking with old openEuler?

already removed deb changes and retested
![image](https://github.com/apache/bigtop/assets/18082602/f40eccef-c8f6-41e2-b6d3-317a14087780)
![image](https://github.com/apache/bigtop/assets/18082602/0a2a8e50-dc6e-4c46-a829-0aff6b215b0b)

> [provisioner/docker/config_openeuler-22.03.yaml](https://github.com/apache/bigtop/blob/0fbaaa90859a889dbd86b869895224fb7126f677/provisioner/docker/config_openeuler-22.03.yaml) should be renamed to config_openeuler-22.03-lts-sp1.yaml and it should refer to `bigtop/puppet:trunk-openeuler-22.03-lts-sp1` as required image.

The code has been modified, thanks.

> @MacChen01 The originally reported issue is conflict between R and openblas-0.18.5.oe2203sp3. Is it not bug of openEuler? We can not expected it to be fixed? How about [installing R from source code as done for old Ubuntu](https://github.com/apache/bigtop/blob/0fbaaa90859a889dbd86b869895224fb7126f677/bigtop_toolchain/manifests/renv.pp#L87-L117) rather than sticking with old openEuler?

when we adapted bigtop in openeuler, using the version of openEuler docker img is 22.03-lts-sp1, other versions have not been released yet, including sp2 and sp3. So the BIGTOP-4082 we didn't met.

> I'm merging this. Thanks, @MacChen01.
> 
> R-core and openblas conflicts even on openeuler-22.03-lst-sp1. If there is no dependency between them, the issue seems to be caused by something pulling openblas in the upstream of 22.03. I will file another JIRA if we can purge openblas in the upstream.
> 
> ```
> [root@a9e272ddcfd6 /]# repoquery -q -l openblas | grep libRblas
> /usr/lib64/R/lib/libRblas.so
> 
> [root@a9e272ddcfd6 /]# repoquery -q -l R-core | grep libRblas
> /usr/lib64/R/lib/libRblas.so
> ```

@iwasakims 
Thanks, if you create new JIRA to track conflicts between  R and openblas, i will also track the JIRA.
Can we review and get this merged @JiaLiangC
@iwasakims please help review the code, thanks.

> @MacChen01 Spark 3.3.4 only supports Python 3.7+, meaning that the default version of Python on many operating systems does not meet this requirement. Simply specifying Python 3 or Python 2 for installation might work, but it won't utilize the system-provided Python. Therefore, the Python requirement in the Spark spec doesn't make sense semantically; a dependency is established, allowing for installation, but it doesn't guarantee usability.
> 
> I believe we can eliminate the Python dependency since Spark's operation does not rely on Python. Only specific functionalities require Python, and users can manually install an appropriate version if needed. Otherwise, managing Spark's Python dependencies within Bigtop would be a disaster.

@JiaLiangC 
Spark has the smoketest about python, and the spark-python is part of spark. 
_Spark's operation does not rely on Python_ ??

Many compents need python, do you create a new JIRA for it?

@iwasakims @guyuqi 
please help review the code, thanks.

@MacChen01 
Yes, logically speaking, testSparkPythonExample should not be able to run successfully on a machine that does not have Python 3 and has a Python version less than 3.7.
Aside from PySpark tasks, other types of Spark tasks do not depend on Python, so I think it would be better to remove the Python dependency in Spark.

@iwasakims @guyuqi
please help review the code, thanks.
@iwasakims please check it again, thanks.

@iwasakims @guyuqi
please help review the code, thanks.

> How about [installing R from source code as done for old Ubuntu](https://github.com/apache/bigtop/blob/0fbaaa90859a889dbd86b869895224fb7126f677/bigtop_toolchain/manifests/renv.pp#L87-L117) rather than sticking with old openEuler?

self reply:  BIGTOP-3967 (#1148) replaced R installed from source with R packaged by thirdpatry (oepkgs). Reverting the related code is an reasonable option.

When I simply tryied to build flink on an arm server with the following

```sh
./gradlew -POS=centos-7 -Pdocker-run-option="--privileged"  bigtop-utils-pkg-ind bigtop-jsvc-pkg-ind bigtop-groovy-pkg-ind flink-pkg-ind
```

I saw

```gradle
> Task :flink-rpm FAILED
++ sed -e 's/[&\\/]/\\&/g; s/$/\\/' -e '$s/\\$//'
+ repl_to='cd \/bigtop \&\& husky install build\/flink\/rpm\/BUILD\/flink-1.16.2\/flink-runtime-web\/web-dashboard\/.husky'
+ sed -i 's/cd ..\/.. \&\& husky install flink-runtime-web\/web-dashboard\/.husky/cd \/bigtop \&\& husky install build\/flink\/rpm\/BUILD\/flink-1.16.2\/flink-runtime-web\/web-dashboard\/.husky/' flink-runtime-web/web-dashboard/package.json
+ scl enable devtoolset-9 -- mvn install -Drat.skip=true -DskipTests -Dhadoop.version=3.3.6
/bigtop/build/flink/rpm//SOURCES/do-component-build: line 45: scl: command not found
error: Bad exit status from /var/tmp/rpm-tmp.2fUp2V (%build)
    Bad exit status from /var/tmp/rpm-tmp.2fUp2V (%build)
```

We might  have to install `scl-utils` to `bigtop-slave`, or I missed some options.

Hmm, I can find scl in my local image. The scl-utils is installed as dependency of devtoolset-9.

```
[root@82798ae56e05 /]# rpm -q --whatrequires scl-utils
devtoolset-9-runtime-9.1-0.el7.aarch64
```

Could you try rebuilding docker image with the patch applied? @yoda-mon 

```
$ docker image rm bigtop/slaves:trunk-centos-7-aarch64
$ docker image rm bigtop/puppet:trunk-centos-7-aarch64
$ ./gradlew -Pprefix=trunk -POS=centos-7 bigtop-slaves
```

@MacChen01 @JiaLiangC I'm +1 on dropping package dependency on python. BIGTOP-4053 looks filed for this.

If we need /usr/bin/python pointing to python3 for smoke-tests on Rocky Linux 9, python-unversioned-command package should be installed by the manifest of bigtop-deploy.

@JiaLiangC How about removing dependency on Python for aligning with other activities in BIGTOP-4052? The manifests of bigtop-deploy must be fixed if you need tweak the environment for running smoke-tests.

@iwasakims 
I agree with removing the Python dependency. I will close this PR.

@iwasakims @guyuqi
please help review the code, thanks.

+1, tested with the following commands. Thanks @iwasakims.

```
$ curl -sL https://patch-diff.githubusercontent.com/raw/apache/bigtop/pull/1258.diff | git apply
$ (cd docker/bigtop-puppet && ./build.sh trunk-openeuler-22.03)
$ (cd docker/bigtop-slaves && ./build.sh trunk-openeuler-22.03)
```

Patching provisioner/utils/setup-env-debian.sh only work for environment launched by the provisioner. If the cause is hard coded path of rm in solrctl, we must apply the patch to it to cover every deployment.

> If the cause is hard coded path of rm in solrctl, we must apply the patch to it to cover every deployment.

If the issue is relevant to upstream Solr, it is recommended to file a Sorl JIRA issue and submit the same patch.

> @timyuer Several years ago some packages do not compatible with Java 11 (For example, Hadoop only supported running on 11 and did not support building with 11) . However, some pakages started to omit suporting 8. I intended to mitigate these situations with adding another options here(I think these situations have been getting well).

@yoda-mon 
I agree that most components of BigTop have started or completed supporting JDK17, so I think this scenario is unnecessary. Moreover, adding a separate JDK option can easily cause ambiguity. I suggest that we use the `BIGTOP_JDK` variable to uniformly control the JDK version.
What do you think?

> @timyuer Several years ago some packages do not compatible with Java 11 (For example, Hadoop only supported running on 11 and did not support building with 11) . However, some pakages started to omit suporting 8. I intended to mitigate these situations with adding another options here(I think these situations have been getting well).

In fact, using the `BIGTOP_JDK` variable can also solve the above problems.

@timyuer 
> I agree that most components of BigTop have started or completed supporting JDK17, so I think this scenario is unnecessary.

I think Hadoop would be the blocker, wouldn't it ? 
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HADOOP-17177

> using the BIGTOP_JDK variable can also solve the above problems.

I think this is partially correct. If you build multi packages with 
- same JDK at the same time
or 
- different JDK  separatelly
it's enough only to use `BIGTOP_JDK`
However, 
- different JDK  at the same time
it's not enough.

> @timyuer
> 
> > I agree that most components of BigTop have started or completed supporting JDK17, so I think this scenario is unnecessary.
> 
> I think Hadoop would be the blocker, wouldn't it ? https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HADOOP-17177
> 
> > using the BIGTOP_JDK variable can also solve the above problems.
> 
> I think this is partially correct. If you build multi packages with
> 
> * same JDK at the same time
>   or
> * different JDK  separatelly
>   it's enough only to use `BIGTOP_JDK`
>   However,
> * different JDK  at the same time
>   it's not enough.

In the third point, using different jdk at the same time can be subdivided into the following two types,
- Using two different versions of JDK at the same time, `BIGTOP_JDK` and `preferred-java-version` can be satisfied.
- Using three or more different versions of JDK at the same time, neither of the above two can be satisfied.

This leads to the following discussion:
1. Is it necessary to use two different JDK compilers at the same time? Will this complicate deployment?
2. If supported, should it also support three or more different JDK compilations at the same time?
I merged this. Thanks, @sekikn.

@iwasakims

Since https://github.com/apache/bigtop/blob/master/bigtop-tests/smoke-tests/solr/build.gradle#L49 causes this, I think we can add some checks on it like `file("/usr/bin/rm").exists()`, what do you think? @MacChen01

@kevinw66 
Yes, as described above, it needs to check the type of OS.
Hi @iwasakims, this is bigtop-select packaging for deb

@arshadmohammad It seems you haven't taken action on the review for several months. Do you still want to continue with this PR? If you don't have time to continue maintaining it, you can close it for now, to ensure that this matter can continue to move forward.

@iwasakims 
Thank you, after clearing cache, the build was successfully finished.

```sh
docker image rm bigtop/slaves:trunk-centos-7-aarch64
docker image rm bigtop/puppet:trunk-centos-7-aarch64
./gradlew -Pprefix=trunk -POS=centos-7 bigtop-slaves

...

BUILD SUCCESSFUL in 29h 30m 5s
```
```sh
./gradlew -POS=centos-7 -Pdocker-run-option="--privileged"  bigtop-utils-pkg-ind bigtop-jsvc-pkg-ind bigtop-groovy-pkg-ind flink-pkg-ind

...

BUILD SUCCESSFUL in 54m 14s
```

And then, smoke tests have passed.

```sh
./gradlew -POS=centos-7 -Pdocker-run-option="--privileged"  hadoop-ind repo-ind
cd provisioner/docker
./docker-hadoop.sh -d -dcp \
  -C config_centos-7.yaml \
  --create 3 \
  --enable-local-repo \
  --repo file:///bigtop-home/output \
  --disable-gpg-check \
  --stack yarn,hdfs,flink \
  --smoke-tests flink
```
Thanks, @yoda-mon. I'm merging this.

@iwasakims @kevinw66 
Thanks
@iwasakims @sekikn @guyuqi Could you help review this PR?
Which CVE is critical?
We should not mention CVEs of Hadoop dependencies as "Hadoop CVE".

@iwasakims Apologies for the confusion caused by the PR title; I will make adjustments.
cve details:

Apache Commons-Configuration2 is vulnerable to a stack overflow vulnerability (CVE-2024-29131).
**1.1 Vulnerability Description**

Apache Commons Configuration2 is a project in the Apache Commons library that deals with the reading, parsing, and management of configuration files.

A stack overflow vulnerability exists in Apache Commons Configuration2 when adding properties in `AbstractListDelimiterHandler.flattenIterator()`, which could be exploited by malicious users to obtain sensitive information stored in memory.
**1.2 Vulnerability ID**
CVE-2024-29131
**1.3 Vulnerability Severity**
Critical
**II. Remediation Suggestions**
**2.1 Affected Versions**
Apache Commons Configuration2 <= 2.10.0
**2.2 Remediation Suggestion**
Users of the product are advised to update to a secure version as soon as possible.
Apache Commons Configuration2 > 2.10.0
https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-configuration/security.html


common-press cve:
https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-compress/security.html

@iwasakims pr title and issue already updated

I've tried to avoid directly modifying operating system files as much as possible. However, in Red Hat 7 series operating systems, once the default Python is set to Python3, it results in Yum becoming unusable. The only solution seems to be modifying Yum . I haven't thought of a more elegant method. If there are any better suggestions, I welcome them.

@iwasakims @sekikn Could you please help review this? Thanks.
@iwasakims Could you help review this pr?

A naive quesiton: seems all OS supports `/usr/bin/python3` directly? Insteaf of enforcing  `python`, why not set `#!/usr/bin/env python3` or explicitly call `python3 xxx`? I saw Spark already did in this way.

@pan3793 
Some components, such as Spark and Ambari, have already explicitly set specific versions of the interpreter. However, in many components like Ranger and gpdb, the interpreter is defined in the Python scripts as #!/usr/bin/env python, so it's necessary to set the default Python to accommodate this scenario.

@iwasakims It seems work well but I have one concern about the Puppet version.

After applying this patch
```sh
./gradlew -Pprefix=trunk -POS=fedora-38 bigtop-puppet
./gradlew -Pprefix=trunk -POS=fedora-38 bigtop-slaves
```
Both builds succeeded. but
```
docker run -it --rm bigtop/puppet:trunk-fedora-38-aarch64  puppet --version
```
showed `8.3.1`. The images that uploads to dockerhub shows `7.27.0` today, and the difference might affect the smoke tests.

This may not be caused by this PR, but we might have to fix the version.

@yoda-mon The images on Docker Hub will be updated by running Jenkins jobs. I will run them after merging this PR.
* https://ci.bigtop.apache.org/job/Docker-Puppet-Trunk/
* https://ci.bigtop.apache.org/job/Docker-Toolchain-Trunk/

If the manifest of bigtop-deploy contains code incompatible with Puppet 8, it should be fixed in follow-up JIRAs.
@kevinw66 How about adding the author of #1158 as co-author on merging this? `root@localhost.localdomain` should be updated to appropriate author too.

> @kevinw66 How about adding the author of #1158 as co-author on merging this? `root@localhost.localdomain` should be updated to appropriate author too.

Thanks for your review, @iwasakims , I think this can be edited directly on the text area that appears after clicking `Squash and merge`, but I can change the commit history if needed.

Actually [deprecation of Hiera 3](https://www.puppet.com/docs/puppet/8/upgrading-from-puppet7-to-puppet8.html#upgrading-from-puppet7-to-puppet8-heira-3-deprecation) affects bigtop-deploy. I will add commit to fix this.

```
Error: Undefined variable 'hadoop_hiera_ha_path' (file: /etc/puppet/hiera.yaml, line: 8) on node 1ac306408ff6.bigtop.apache.org
```

puppet 8 packaged by fedora-38 is coupled with hiera 3. I guess the error is caused by just variable lookup settings.

```
[root@495d41ec7cd8 /]# rpm -q hiera
hiera-3.11.0-2.fc38.noarch

[root@495d41ec7cd8 /]# rpm -q --whatrequires hiera
puppet-8.3.1-1.fc38.noarc
```

The current manifest [tries to conditionaly switch hiera file](https://github.com/apache/bigtop/blob/3808ba7d1b8d6c2504c08ed9079a9d5673ae83de/bigtop-deploy/puppet/hiera.yaml#L6) based on [the variable in class](https://github.com/apache/bigtop/blob/3808ba7d1b8d6c2504c08ed9079a9d5673ae83de/bigtop-deploy/puppet/manifests/cluster.pp#L158-L163). We can not assume that the class local variable is visible. We should switch ha/non-ha by explicit declaration in site.yaml.
The cause of the error turned out to be bug of the manifest rather than Puppet version. smoke-tests of Hadoop passed on both fedora-38 and centos-7 with the updated manifest.
@yoda-mon Could you take a look again? This issue blocks release of Bigtop 3.3.0.
@sekikn Could you review this? I need to fix this to move Bigtop 3.3.0 release forward.

Could you help review this PR?

> So, do we need to install these Python dependencies during deployment?
